section.title: General Principles of Loan Amortization
section.p: When a loan is paid off, each payment K_t has two components: the amount of interest paid I_t, and the amount of principal paid, Pr_t:
This notation sometimes vary from one text to another, so just be sure to understand the symbols you are using in any given context.

When loans are paid off, we say the loan is amortized. The word amortization refers to the payment of an original loan amount L carrying a periodic interest rate \iota with periodic payments K_t. Sometimes there are different interest rates over different periods. Note that sometimes repayment schedules with constant payments (K_t = K for all t) is referred to as amortization or "the amortization method." We try to avoid such terms in this book, but generally you can determine what the author means by context.

There are two general principles for loan amortization. The first is that the outstanding balance at any point in time is the present value of the remaining payments. In other words: OB_t = K_{t+1}v + K_{t+2}v^2 + \cdots + K_nv^{n-t} Note that OB_0 = L and as a consequence: L = K_1v + K_2v^2 + \cdots K_nv^n
The second principle is what I call the recursive nature of amortization. If we start with OB_{t-1}, interest is accrued on this outstanding balance before the payment is applied.

An amortized loan has 10 annual payments at the end of each year starting one year from now. The first 5 payments are 1000 each and the final 5 payments are 500 each. Interest is at an effective annual rate of 10%. Find each of the following:

assemblage.title: 🧮 Calculator Corner
assemblage.p: The financial calculator includes an amortization worksheet This worksheet will tell you how much principal and how much interest is in a given payment, as well as the balance immediately following the payment. It can only be used when your are amortizing with constant payments (K_t = K for all t).
To use the amortization worksheet, first enter all of the data that you have about the loan using N, I/Y, PV, PMT, and FV. Have the calculator calculate any missing values.

Once that is entered, hit the AMORT button (hit 2ND followed by the PV button). For P1, enter the payment number you want to look at, and hit ENTER. Then hit the button, and for P2, enter the same payment number and hit ENTER (if P1 and P2 are different, the calculator will report the cumulative impact, as we will see later!).

Then you can use the and buttons and see the outstanding balance immediately after the payment (BAL), the principal repaid in the payment (PRN), and the interest in the payment (INT). The principal and interest payments will display as negative due to the sign convention of the calculator.

statement.p: Use the financial calculator to redo the previous question. Do you prefer to use the amortization worksheet or amortizing by hand?

section.p: Almost every problem we will examine will involve a loan being repaid by one of three approaches:

li.p: Constant payments: K_t = K for all t (the most common approach),
Constant payments of principal: Pr_t = Pr for all t, or
Payment of interest only (I_t = I = \iota L for all t), with principal paid off at the end.

introduction.p: You might run into a problem that does not quite fit into one of the three repayment approaches we outlined above. In these cases, it is helpful to write out two or three rows of an amortization schedule and look for patterns. To find patterns, it is helpful to write out your calculation steps.

task.p: A 30-year loan of 1000 is repaid with payments at the end of each year. Each of the first ten payments equals the amount of interest due. Each of the next ten payments equals 150% of the amount of interest due. Each of the last ten payments is X. The lender charges interest at an effective annual rate of 10%. Calculate X.
We can characterize the repayment in the middle ten payments in this problem as payment by multiples of interest. We could derive formulas for such a repayment scheme. Is it worth it? Why or why not?
